quizzes.question: Which HTML element is needed to collect user input from a web page?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Forms[/h1] The purpose of the PHP superglobals [b]$_GET[/b] and [b]$_POST[/b] is to collect data that has been entered into a form. The example below shows a simple HTML form that includes two input fields and a submit button:[code format="raw"]

quizzes.question: Which form attribute indicates the page to which the form is submitted?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Forms[/h1]

The [b]action[/b] attribute specifies that when the form is submitted, the data is sent to a PHP file named [b]first.php[/b]. 
HTML form elements have [b]names[/b], which will be used when accessing the data with PHP.
[note]The [b]method [/b]attribute will be discussed in the next lesson. For now, we'll set the value to "[b]post[/b]".[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to submit the form to a page called my.php using the POST method.
[!raw!]
<form action="{0}"
 {1}="post">
 </form>
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Forms[/h1] Now, when we have an HTML form with the [b]action [/b]attribute set to our PHP file, we can access the posted form data using the[b] $_POST[/b] associative array. In the [b]first.php[/b] file: [code format="raw" ] Welcome
Your age: [/code] The [b]$_POST[/b] superglobal array holds key/value pairs. In the pairs, keys are the [b]names[/b] of the form controls and values are the[b] input data[/b] entered by the user. [note]We used the [b]$_POST [/b]array, as the [b]method="post[/b]" was specified in the form. To learn more about the form methods, press [b]Continue[/b]![/note]
